text: sharing a home cooked meal on a
weeknight when you're working all day is
not such an easy task but there is one
secret weapon that you really should
have in your kitchen that makes it so
much easier and that's the old slow
cooker this recipe for slow cooker
marmalade and vinegar pork is so easy it
takes less than 20 minutes to put
together and you can do it all in the
morning before you head off to work and
it starts with this beautiful piece of
boneless pork shoulder four and a half
pounds and you'll want to trim the
excess fat that fat cap is really
beautiful but we don't want all of that
in there the cut itself is also marbled
with lots of fat that will melt into the
braise as it cooks neathia cut into
2-inch pieces this meat will shrink and
become fork tender as it cooks all day
long and then we can cut this into
playings that's probably about two
inches right there down the middle this
would also work beautifully with a cut
of beef now into 2-inch pieces and as
you're working you can chuck it right
into the slow cooker this is a generous
recipe could easily feed eight people
while most of your work here is already
done before we add the rest of the
ingredients we just need to season the
pork generously with salt and pepper
makes for less mess easier cleanup and
lots and lots of freshly ground black
pepper and just give that a quick toss
now for the braising liquid start with a
quarter cup of red wine vinegar four
cloves of garlic that have been peeled
and smashed with the side of a knife
half a teaspoon of red pepper flakes
really is necessary to balance the
sweetness of the marmalade and this is
three-quarters of a cup of orange
marmalade now marmalade unlike a jam has
the zest of the orange in it gives a
fuller flavor and that little bit of
bitterness from the zest and a sprig of
rosemary I like to rub the herb in my
hand for a moment to release that
wonderful smell and those essential oils
the lib
of a stir and one more aromatic a
teaspoon of fennel seeds just toast them
briefly so in that goes give that a good
stir to combine and that pours right on
over the pork looks pretty dry at the
moment but as it braises throughout the
day that pork is going to release all of
its juices and inform the flavor of that
braising liquid quick toss to ensure
that you've got all of that pork evenly
coated pop on the lid turn on too low
and if you have one that you can't i'm
set your timer for eight hours and
you're ready to grab your keys and head
out the door let's cook up some couscous
it's excellent with this dish I have two
cups of couscous in a bowl here and to
that add two cups of boiling hot water
you can measure but if you just do water
to cover that's all you need just like
that and just like half teaspoon of
coarse salt and about two teaspoons of
extra virgin olive oil okay and then
we'll stir that all about after it's
cooked you don't even have to boil
couscous the hot water is enough to
soften the grain we can set that aside
for a moment and take a look at our pork
oh yes that looks good now there's a lot
of fat in here that we're going to need
to remove so the first thing to do is to
pull out the meat using a slotted spoon
into a bowl you can see how much smaller
those pieces of pork have become as
they've cooked to all day long smells
and really good now for the sauce let's
strain it quickly
you can see how much liquid ok that's
all of our braising liquid there and now
2d fat it you can just take a spoon if
you have a de fatter they look kind of
like a wet measure cup those are
excellent as well but this does the job
ok I think that's most of it I like to
leave a little bit of fat behind for
flavor that looks good now let's check
in on our couscous yeah this is ready to
fluff that was what maybe five minutes
not even give it a good stir with a fork
ok and into this goes some watercress
it's nice peppery crunchy green we want
to put about half of this bunch i think
into the couscous you'll want about half
a cup of chopped to watercress to stir
into your couscous and the rest will
stir in whole sprigs now those thick
stems at the bottom you'll want to leave
out there a little tough so that goes in
let me show you how to serve this first
our couscous studded with watercress a
nice generous spoonful or two in the
bowl mm-hmm our pork
giving myself a generous portion today
YUM and that braising liquid lots and
lots of that right over the top and to
finish one more little touch a wedge of
orange squeezed over the top to
reinforce the flavor of the marmalade
and it's also nice to serve a few wedges
alongside for eating how gorgeous is
that easy inexpensive and absolutely
delicious pull out your slow cooker and
make this tonight happy eating
you
